anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 4th June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature of Punjab at Simla

The appellant Bhagwan Singh has been convicted of the murder of one Buggar Singh and sentenced to death. He has also been convicted under section 19 f  of the Indian Arms Act but we are not concerned with that here.

holdings.text: The Sessions Court has power to examine witnesses who were not examined before the Committing Magistrate because of section 540 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: It is evident that the Sessions Court has power to examine witnesses who were not examined before the Committing Magistrate because of section 540 of the Criminal Procedure Code,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory power under s540 CrPC explicitly allows summoning material witnesses at any stage; complete answer to objection.

holdings.text: If the witness is treated as a prosecution witness and examined by the prosecuting counsel instead of by the Court itself that at best would be an irregularity curable by section 537.

anchor.surface_text: examined by the prosecuting counsel instead of by the Court itself that at best would be an irregularity curable by section 537.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural irregularity in manner of examination under s540 curable under s537 absent objection at trial.

holdings.text: Section 540 is a complete answer; none of the cases cited goes so far as to say that a witness who was not produced in the committal proceedings can be examined at the trial.

anchor.surface_text: through the provisions of Chapter XVIII of the Criminal Procedure Code and stressed in particular section 208 (1) but

holdings.reasoning_summary: s540 overrides committal restrictions in Chapter XVIII; precedents concede power and focus on prejudice which is absent.

holdings.text: The appellant was not taken by surprise and no prejudice was occasioned.

anchor.surface_text: he had the right to demand a copy under section 162 and if he did not do so,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witness named in FIR and committal calendar; right to s162 copy not exercised; testimony within FIR scope; no objection raised.

holdings.text: The learned High Court Judges were not using the former statements as substantive evidence but merely as corroboration of what was said in chief.

anchor.surface_text: despite the fact that it was legally inadmissible for that purpose because the formalities prescribed by section 288 were not observed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior statements used under s157 Evidence Act for corroboration, not contradiction; s288 applies subject to Evidence Act provisions like s157; independent evidence of PW5/PW6 sufficient.

holdings.text: Section 145 is not called into play at all in such a case. Resort to section 145 would only be necessary if the witness denies that he made the former statement.

anchor.surface_text: Section 145 is not called into play at all in such a case. Resort to section 145 would only be necessary if

holdings.reasoning_summary: When witness admits prior statement, no need for s145 contradiction procedure; used for corroboration under s157; substantial compliance anyway with point-by-point attention and full reading.

holdings.text: The Court is bound to accept this as correct under section 80 of the Indian Evidence Act until it is proved to be untrue.

anchor.surface_text: The Court is bound to accept this as correct under section 80 of the Indian Evidence Act until it is proved to be untrue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory presumption from magistrate's certificate on deposition; burden on challenger not discharged; no duty to examine magistrate.

holdings.text: Even if the deposition was not read over, that would only amount to a curable irregularity and, in the absence of prejudice... there is no point in the objection.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the reading over prescribed by section 360 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is not to enable

holdings.reasoning_summary: s360 requires reading for accurate record, not story change; curable absent specific affidavit of prejudice/inaccuracy.

holdings.text: It is not part of a Court's duty to enter upon a roving enquiry in the middle of a trial on matters which are collateral to the main issue.

anchor.surface_text: there was no proper compliance with the provisions. of section 342 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on accused to substantiate threats/duress claims; court not bound to believe unsupported testimony or conduct enquiry.

holdings.text: There was substantial compliance with the provisions of section 342 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: there was no proper compliance with the provisions. of section 342 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Simple facts adequately put to accused; no prejudice shown or specific alternative answers disclosed.

holdings.text: The conviction can be rested on the testimony of Balbir Singh PW5 and Jaswant Singh PW6.

holdings.text: Certain irregularities in the trial do not vitiate it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All procedural objections rejected on statutory cures, lack of prejudice, substantial compliance.

anchor.surface_text: The decision most in favour of the appellants companytention is Sher Bahadur v. The Crown  1 but that does numbermore than companysider such an omission as a curable defect. Abdul Qadir J. said at pages 338 and 342 that it was companyceded before them that section 540 companyld be called in aid in such a case, and at page 339 the learned Judge dealt with the question of prejudice  1  1934 I.L.R. 15 lah.331.

precedents.cited_proposition: Omission to examine a witness before the committing magistrate is a curable defect; section 540 CrPC can be invoked; decision turned on prejudice caused by withholding multiple witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised in Queen-Empress v. G.W. Hayfield 1  does number arise here because the Sessions Court did number refuse to examine Jaswant Singh, P.W. 6, and so the question whether the prosecution companyld demand his examina- tion as a matter of right never arose. 1   1892  I.L.R. 14 All. 212.

precedents.cited_proposition: Whether prosecution can demand as of right the examination of a witness by committing magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Allahabad High Court in S.H. Jhabwala v. Emperor  2 and the Full Bench of the Lahore High Court in Mussammat Niamat v. The Crown 3  are against the learned companysels companytention. 2 A.I.R. 1933 All. 690.

precedents.cited_proposition: Witness not examined before committing magistrate can be examined at sessions trial.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Allahabad High Court in S.H. Jhabwala v. Emperor  2 and the Full Bench of the Lahore High Court in Mussammat Niamat v. The Crown 3  are against the learned companysels companytention. 3   Z936 I.L.R. 17 Lah. 176.

precedents.cited_proposition: Witness not examined before committing magistrate can be examined at sessions trial.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Full Bench of the Lower Burma Chief Court in Emperor v. Channing Arnold  4  is number in point because the Committing Magistrate there refused to examine witnesses which the prosecution wanted, 4   1912 13 Cr. L,.J. 877.

precedents.cited_proposition: Committing magistrate refused prosecution witnesses and prevented cross-examination of examined witness.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed upon Tara Singh v. The State 1 . Even if that be so, it would make numberdifference because the evidence of Balbir Singh and Jaswant Singh, whom the learned Judges primarily believe, is sufficient to afford a basis for the companyviction 1  1951 S.C.R. 729.

precedents.cited_proposition: Evidence before committing magistrate cannot be used as substantive evidence without formalities under section 288 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Tara Singh v. The State 1  is to be distinguished because there, there were numbertwo versions in the companyrse of the same testimony. The witness in question was hostile from the start in the Sessions Court 1  1951 S.C.R. 729 at 743.

precedents.cited_proposition: Previous statement used to contradict hostile witness from start, no choice of corroboration.

precedents.citation: Kashmira Singh v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1

anchor.surface_text: we endorse the re- marks we made in Kashmira Singh v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1  based on the decision of the Privy Council in Nazir Ahmad v. King Emperor 2  1  1952 S.C.R. 526.

precedents.case_name: Kashmira Singh v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Undesirability of examining committing magistrate to prove truth of certificate under section 80 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: based on the decision of the Privy Council in Nazir Ahmad v. King Emperor 2  regarding the undesirability of any such practice. 2 A.I.R. 1936 P.C. 253 at 258.

precedents.cited_proposition: Undesirability of examining committing magistrate to prove truth of his certificate.

anchor.surface_text: as the Privy Council observed in Abdul Rahman v. King Emperor  3 , in the absence of prejudice which must be disclosed in an affidavit which shows exactly where the record departs from what the witness actually said, 3 A.I.R 1927 P.C. 44 at 45-47.

precedents.cited_proposition: Failure to read over deposition is curable irregularity absent specific prejudice shown by affidavit detailing inaccuracies.

anchor.surface_text: We pressed him several times to disclose that but he was unable to do so. As we said at the outset, the case is a very simple one in which a man was caught red-handed with a pistol still in his hand and in which the first information report was recorded practically on the spot within 15 minutes of the occurrence.
